title: Man forgot gun in vehicle before son, 3, shot mother in head
content:
KENTWOOD, MI - A man told police he forgot that he'd left his gun in his vehicle before his 3-year-old son found it and fired the weapon, hitting the boy's mother in the head.
The woman was not seriously injured.
Kentwood police reports did not name the parents but other sources identified them as Michele and Jacob Hanson.
The incident occurred around 2:35 p.m. Feb. 20 at the Hansons' home at 5745 East Grove Drive SE.
The father told investigators he was in his kitchen when he heard a gunshot coming from the garage. His wife was in the front passenger seat of their Chevrolet Traverse.
Their son was in the front seat holding a 9mm pistol.
The father took the gun and noted it had jammed after the first shot. He then helped his wife onto the driveway and called 911, reports said.
The woman told police she was sitting in the front passenger seat vacuuming while her son helped clean the sport-utility vehicle.
She told police that "she looked down and heard a loud bang. (She) said she thought something had fallen and hit her in the head, and when she looked up (the boy) was holding the gun. (She) said she started screaming ... ."
The father told police that he has a license to carry a concealed pistol. He usually has the weapon holstered when outside of his vehicle. When he is inside the vehicle, he usually secures it in the door compartment.
The father told police that earlier in the day, the family was out running errands when neighbors, who are moving, said they wanted to get together. When they got home, they visited the neighbors, then went back home.
At home, he typically secures it in a gun safe. He told police he must have been in a rush to see his neighbors and forgot to put it away.
He "stated he does not typically leave his pistol in the car, however, he had been out running errands and had forgotten to take it out," police reports said.
One of the neighbors they had visited earlier rushed over after hearing the gunshot. She could see the boy standing inside the vehicle. She helped get the victim to the driveway.
She recalled hearing someone say, "The gun was in the door of the car."
Police said the victim was taken to a hospital. She was treated and released later that day.
Chief Assistant Kent County Prosecutor Chris Becker said Jacob Hanson legally owned the firearm.
